# Draft:Martin Thomas (Australian historian)

thumb
Martin Edward Thomas (born 1964), usually known as Martin Thomas, is an Australian historian, documentary maker, and oral historian. He is Professor of History at the Australian National University in Canberra.
Early life and education
Martin Thomas attended Pennant Hills High School in northwest Sydney. In 1983 he worked at Lake Vyrnwy in Wales, the subject of his radio essay Returning to Wales (2005).  He later studied at the University of Sydney, graduating with Honours in History. In 1988 he began to work as an independent essayist, critic, and writer/producer for ABC Radio. In 1995 he began doctoral research at the University of Technology, Sydney (UTS) where he later worked as a postdoctoral fellow.  His PhD thesis was published as The Artificial Horizon: Imagining the Blue Mountains (2003).
Career
Thomas has published on Australian and trans-national cultural history, especially as it relates to perceptions of place, representations of landscape, and narratives of cross-cultural encounter. He has worked extensively on early Australian anthropology and the history of exploration.  Since the release of his edited book Expedition into Empire (2014) he has become known for his work on the expedition as a socio-cultural formation.  His critical engagement with histories of exploration has involved long-term, collaborative research with Indigenous communities, especially in northern Australia where he studied the impact of the 1948 American-Australian Scientific Expedition to Arnhem Land.  This has opened new perspectives on how expeditions are understood by cultures that were allegedly ‘explored’ by outsiders.
Thomas was a research fellow at the University of Sydney in the early 2000s. He had a Smithsonian Fellowship in 2008 where he studied collections relating to the American-Australian Scientific Expedition to Arnhem Land.
In 2010 he joined the Australian National University as an Australian Research Council Future Fellow, later becoming Professor of History.  In 2018 he was announced as the Keith Cameron Chair in Australian history at University College Dublin.  In 2020-21 he was Visiting Co-Director of the Menzies Australia Institute at King’s College London.
As an academic, he has made works for radio and co-produced a feature-length documentary film. He is also an oral history interviewer for the National Library of Australia.
Indigenous human remains
Thomas is an advocate for the repatriation of Indigenous ancestral remains that were stolen or collected in the name of science. He has done detailed research on the scientific collecting of human remains and its impact upon Indigenous beliefs about the spirit world and the afterlife.  These themes are explored in the film Etched in Bone (co-produced with Béatrice Bijon) (2018), the essay ‘Because It’s Your Country’ (2013), and the book Clever Men (2025).
Recognition and honours
2025. Winner: Mark & Evette Moran Nib Literary Award for Clever Men How Worlds Collided on the Scientific Expedition to Arnhem Land of 1948
2019: Short-listed: Council of Humanities and Social Sciences Australia (CHASS) Prize for Distinctive Work for Etched in Bone
2019. Short-listed: Digital History Prize, New South Wales Premier’s History Awards for Etched in Bone
2013. Winner of Australian Book Review’s Calibre Prize for an Outstanding Essay for ‘“Because it’s Your Country”: Bringing Back the Bones to west Arnhem Land’
2012. Winner of the National Biography Award of Australia for The Many Worlds of R. H. Mathews: In search of an Australian anthropologist
2004. Winner of the Gleebooks Prize for Literary and Cultural Criticism, New South Wales Premier’s Literary Awards for The Artificial Horizon: Imagining the Blue Mountains
2000. Winner of the Premier’s Audio/Visual History Prize, New South Wales Premier’s History Awards for the ABC radio program This is Jimmie Barker
Publications
Books (sole author)
Thomas, Martin (2001).  A Multicultural Landscape: National Parks & the Macedonian Experience. Sydney: Pluto Press
——  (2003). The Artificial Horizon: Imagining the Blue Mountains. Melbourne: Melbourne University Press
——  (2011). The Many Worlds of R. H. Mathews: In Search of an Australian Anthropologist. Sydney: Allen & Unwin
——  (2025). Clever Men: How Worlds Collided on the Scientific Expedition to Arnhem Land of 1948. Sydney: Allen & Unwin
Books (edited)
——  (1999). Uncertain Ground: Essays Between Art & Nature. Sydney: Art Gallery of New South Wales
——  (2007). Culture in Translation: The anthropological legacy of R. H. Mathews. Canberra: ANU Press in association with Aboriginal History Monographs
——  (2011). Exploring the Legacy of the 1948 Arnhem Land Expedition (co-edited with Margo Neale). Canberra: ANU Press
——  (2014). Expedition into Empire: Exploratory Journeys and the Making of the Modern World. London and New York: Routledge
——  (2018). Expeditionary Anthropology: Travel, teamwork and the ‘science of man’ (co-edited with Amanda Harris). Oxford and New York: Berghahn Books
——  (2024). A Cultural History of Exploration in the Modern Age. London: Bloomsbury Academic
Documentary Film
——  (2019). Etched in Bone (director, narrator, and, with Béatrice Bijon, co-producer (duration 73 minutes). Canberra: Red Lily Productions in association with Ronin Films
Works for Radio (selected)
——  (1991). Home Front Manhattan (audio essay on homelessness and the Gulf War) (duration 56 minutes). First broadcast on ‘The Listening Room’, ABC-FM, 5 August, 1991
——  (1997). Stony Silences. (Radio essay on the Three Sisters rock  formation in the Blue Mountains) (duration 54 minutes). First broadcast on 'Radio Eye', ABC Radio National, August 1997.
——  (2000). This is Jimmie Barker. (Radio documentary about the Muruwari sound recordist, based on Barker's original recordings) (duration 56 minutes). First broadcast on Radio Eye, ABC Radio National on 25 March 2000
——  (2002). Symphony in Stone. (Radio essay inspired by Victor Hugo and the acoustic environment of Notre Dame Cathedral in Paris) (duration 57 minutes). First broadcast on The Listening Room, ABC Classic FM, 1 April 2002.
——  (2005). Returning to Wales. (Memoir for radio about Lake Vyrnwy and the flooding of the village of Llanwddyn in Wales) (duration 57 minutes). First broadcast on Radio Eye, ABC Radio National, 25 June 2005.
